CHIEF COMPLAINT: Right Groin Pain
SUBJECTIVE: 
___, an ___ yo F PMHx CKD III baseline Cr 1.6, HTN, 
T2DM presents with groin rash/pruritis. Two weeks prior to 
presentation, patient developed groin pruritis and rash. 
Pruritis improved with vagisil but the pruritis continued, 
patient noticed discharged, and patient felt it should be 
examined by a physician. Patient in area since brother is 
currently inpatient on Farr11. She reports that she has had 
decreased oral and fluid intake. She has been feeling slightly 
lightheaded. She denies any fevers, chills, chest pain, SOB, 
palpitations, dysuria, hematuria, vaginal discharge, increasing 
frequency, back pain.
In the ED, initial VS were: 97.2 63 113/74 18 100% RA. Labs were 
notable for: WBC 6.6 with PMNs 70.8. Eos 5.0. Chem7 with Cr 2.7 
(baseline ___ as per renal note), K 5.9 HCO3 14. 
lactate 0.9. VBG 7.18 / 38 / 50. Repeat labs were notable for K 
5.6 with HCO3 14 and Cr downtrended to 2.5. She did have an 
episode of asymptomatic bradycardia. Rectal exam was negative. 
CXR showed central pulmonary vascular engorgement. Mildly 
prominent right hilum. Renal was called and recommended medical 
management without any acute indication for dialysis. EP was 
consulted given the patient's atrial fibrillation with 
bradycardia that they attributed to hyperkalemia and acidemia. 
She was given Vancomcyin, ceftriaxone, and insulin. Her vitals 
prior to transfer were: 98.4 60 142/49 18 99% RA.
In FICU, her creatinine trended downward with IVF and holding 
lisinopril. Hyperkalemia was managed with several doses of 
insulin/D50 in addition to Bicarb. Nephrology consult 
recommended D5/Bicarbonate as they felt she most likely 
secondary to an RTA. Renal ultrasound negative for 
hydronephrosis (but did not use doppler). Patient had no EKG 
changes and was kept on ceftriaxone. She requested to come to 
the ___ to be close to her brother.
This morning on CC7, patient feels overall similar to 
presentation, feeling tired/fatigued, hasnÂ’t been out of bed, 
and her pruritis from right groin is improved.  She feels out of 
place since she usually lives in the ___.

IMAGING:
=============
Chest X-Ray: Central pulmonary vascular engorgement. Mildly 
prominent right hilum may be due to vascular engorgement but 
underlying lymphadenopathy is not excluded. Findings could be 
further assessed on a nonurgent chest CT.  

Renal Ultrasound: No hydronephrosis. Mild bilateral renal 
cortical thinning.  Small amount of free fluid adjacent to the 
left kidney.

Echocardiogram: The left atrium is mildly dilated. No left 
atrial mass/thrombus seen (best excluded by transesophageal 
echocardiography). The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ 
mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function 
(LVEF>55%). The estimated cardiac index is normal 
(>=2.5L/min/m2). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased 
left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic 
stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The 
mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral 
regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. EF>65%.  
IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
preserved regional and global biventricular systolic function. 
Mild mitral regurgitation. Pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension. Increased PCWP.

Brief Hospital Course:
___, an ___ yo F PMHx CKD III baseline Cr 1.6, HTN, 
T2DM presents with groin rash/pruritis complicated by acute on 
chronic kidney disease with hyperkalemia/metabolic acidosis and 
atrial fibrillation with slowed ventricular rate. Her 
hyperkalemia, AoCKD, and acidosis resolved with IV hydration, 
bicarbonate infusions, dextrose/insulin, and laxatives including 
kayexolate (were stable >24 hours without intervention prior to 
discharge). Her groin cellulitis (likely in setting of candidal 
intertrigo) was initially treated with vancomycin/ceftriaxone 
and narrowed to amoxicillin-clavulanate/doxycline along with 
miconazole powder with continued improvement in signs/symptoms 
and lack of fever. She was noted to have atrial fibrillation 
with ventricular rates ___ (no clear lightheadedness, 
presyncope, chest pain, or dyspnea); per patient she had this 
for ___ years but per PCP notes and EKGs patient had no history 
of this from ___ onward. Patient was started on apixaban in 
discussion with patient, inpatient team, cardiology, and primary 
team. ___ recommended ___ rehab given deconditioning and 
health situation of her brother.

# Atrial Fibrillation with Slow Ventricular Response / 
Asymptomatic Bradycardia: Per patient report she has had atrial 
fibrillation for years (CHADS 3 for HTN, Age, DM but not on 
anticoagulation or rate/rhythm control) but currently noted to 
be in persistent/permanent atrial fibrillation with slowed 
ventricular response (likely worsened in the setting of 
hyperkalemia and acidemia).  However her electrical rhythm did 
not normalize with normalization of electrolytes.  ICU consulted 
Electrophysiology Consult who felt that she she be 
anticoagulated and should followup with an outpatient 
cardiologist.  She was put on apixaban 2.5mg PO BID (due to age 
and renal function), was monitored on telemetry (AFib with HR 
generally 40-60s occasionally ___ or ___, and an echocardiogram 
showed only mild structural heart disease.

# Hyperkalemia / Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis / Acute on 
Chronic Kidney Disease: Patient with CKD Stage III presents with 
Cr 2.7 from 1.5-1.6 baseline in setting of poor PO intake as 
well as hyperkalemia and nonunion gap metabolic acidosis.  
Nephrology was consulted for assistance.  ___ is likely a 
prerenal process given improvement with IVF (renal ultrasound 
unremarkable aside from mild cortical thickening with normal LDH 
nonsuggestive of infearction, urine electrolytes suggest a 
sodium-conserving process).  Hyperkalemia is most likely 
multifactorial with ___ and acidemia contributing possibly with 
concomitant renal tubular acidosis. ___ have component of 
chronic respiratory acidosis from obesity hypoventilation.  
Bradycardia most likely secondary to acidemia and elevated K but 
no evidence of other ECG changes.  Patient would most likely 
have Type IV RTA given diabetes mellitus and hyperkalemia this 
this is a challenging diagnosis to make in the setting of ___.  
From ___, she was given several doses of insulin/D50, 
kayexolate, calcium carbonate, and 5 liters of intravenous 
bicarbonate with resolution of her hyperkalemia and metabolic 
acidosis.  On ___, her electrolytes and renal function 
normalized and were maintained from ___ without interventions. 
Lisinopril was held due to advanced age, near-normotension, and 
concern for future hyperkalemia.

# Groin Rash / Candidal Intertrigo with Secondary Bacterial 
Cellulitis: Patient noted to have right groin erythema/pruritis 
for 2 weeks prior to admission (possibly secondary to lack of 
ability to do laudry at home). Topical antifungals improved the 
pruritis but not the rash and patient began to have systemic 
symptoms (poor PO intake, malaise, ___. Differential includes 
cellulitis (but improvement with topical antifungals, maybe be 
superimposed on intertriginous process) versus ___ 
intertrigo (no satellite lesions, fluid filled vesicles).  
Antibiotic regimen was initialy vancomycin/ceftriaxone, stepped 
down to ceftriaxone, and finally to 
amoxicillin-clavulanate/doxycycline for total course of 7 days.  
She was continued on Amox-Clav and Doxycyline through ___ and 
Miconazole Powder through ___.

# Acute Gout Flare: Patient complained of pain in left and right 
___ MTP joints and was noted at 11:15 on ___ to have a red 
swollen and clearly tender ___ right MTP joint.  Due to 
precarious renal function (contraindications to NSAIDs and 
colcichine), patient was started on prednisone 40mg PO daily x3 
days (given resolution of symptoms within 24 hours of treatment) 
30mg x3 days, 20mg x3 days, 10mg x3 days then discontinuation.  

# Type II Diabetes Mellitus on oral medications: Chronic stable 
issue on ISS and diabetic diet with home glipizide being held as 
inpatient; due to overall stability of her diabetes her 
fingersticks were reduced to AM fasting with sliding scale 
starting at >200 but this was reconsidered due to use of 
corticosteroids for gout.  

# Hypertension: Chronic stable issue continued on home 
amlodipine but lisinopril held given ___.  Her 
systolic blood pressures in house were maintained between 
110-150s.  

TRANSITIONAL ISSUE:
- Started on doxycycline and amoxicillin-clavulanate through 
___ for inguinal cellulitis
- Started on miconazole powder through ___ for candidal 
intertrigo
- Started on apixaban for atrial fibrillation with CHADS Score 3
- Started on prednisone 40mg for brief course for gout treatment 
(concerns about colchicine and NSAIDs, continued on insulin 
sliding scale for longer period given likely hyperglycemia); 
given renal function may be a candidate for permanent gout 
prophylaxis
- Discontinued lisinopril given ___ and hyperkalemia
- Creatinine 1.5 on discharge with normal electrolytes
- Code Status; Full Code
- Contact: Patient, Brother
- ___ Rehab

Hypertension
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure to take care of you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital because you 
had an infection of your groin, a very slow heart rate, and poor 
kidney function with resulting electrolyte problems.  We gave 
you IV fluids and medications to reduce your potassium and your 
kidney function went back to its previous function. We gave you 
antibiotics which are successfully treating your cellulitis.  We 
also monitored your heart rate (stable but irregular, not 
causing symptoms) and put you on medications to make sure that 
this heart rhythm won't cause strokes.  We also had Physical 
Therapy evaluate you to make sure you would be safe at home; 
they felt you would be best served with rehab.  We also gave you 
a short course of steroids for your gout.  Best of luck to you 
in your future health.

Please take all medications as prescribed, attend all doctors 
___ as ___, and call a doctor if you have any 
questions or concerns.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
